title: Monthly Business Survey - Construction and Allied Trades

list: Data should relate to all sites in England, Scotland and Wales but excludes Northern Ireland.
You can provide informed estimates if actual figures are not available.
We will treat your data securely and confidentially.

content.description: You will be asked to provide information on the value of work undertaken by your business and the number of employees. Value of work refers to estimates of chargeable work carried out during the month; meaning work started, in progress, or completed.
This section asks for information on the value of new builds and repair and maintenance (R&M), improvements and major alterations on housing for public and private sector projects.

list: You cannot appeal your selection. Your business was selected to give us a comprehensive view of the UK economy.
The information you provide contributes to Gross Domestic Product (GDP). The Monthly Business Survey figures are published monthly in the Output in the Construction Industry Statistical Bulletin.

content.description: This refers to all work on new structures and repair and maintenance (R&M) on existing structures, carried out on housing, infrastructure, commercial and industrial projects for the public and private sector.

blocks.title: Housing work
blocks.description:
This section asks for information on the value of new builds and repair and maintenance (R&M), improvements and major alterations on housing for public and private sector projects.

You will be asked to provide information on the value of work undertaken by your business. Value of work refers to estimates of chargeable work carried out during the month; meaning work started, in progress, or completed.

Include:

  • work on buildings which you hope to sell later for profit (speculative work)
  • work done by your business on its own premises
  • fixtures, equipment and tools your business made and used in construction
  • materials your business used, overheads and profits
  • labour costs on your payroll

Exclude:

  • VAT
  • payments made to subcontractors
  • payments made to consultants or architects
  • fixtures, equipment and tools your business made for sale
  • materials your business sold
  • value of land

questions.title: During the period {{ metadata['ref_p_start_date'] | format_date }} to {{ metadata['ref_p_end_date'] | format_date }}, did {{ first_non_empty_item(metadata['trad_as'], metadata['ru_name']) }} carry out any work on housing?
questions.description: If you are a fitter or installer, you are included within the construction industry sector so should report your figures.

content.description: Include new builds and repair and maintenance (R&M) of:

list: any work on halls of residence for educational institutions

definitions.title: What we mean by "work on housing"

content.description: This refers to work on residential buildings. If over half of a building's floor area is used for residential purposes, it is considered a residential building.

options.label: Yes, we carried out work on housing
options.value: Yes, we carried out work on housing

options.label: No, we did not carry out work on housing
options.value: No, we did not carry out work on housing

values: Yes, we carried out work on housing

options.description: In the UK, the public sector consists of five sub-sectors: central government, local government, public non-financial corporations, Bank of England, public financial corporations (public sector banks)

options.label: Private sector projects
options.description: The private sector refers to the part of the economy that is for profit and is owned by private organisations, for example housing associations, or individuals

blocks.title: Infrastructure
blocks.description:
This section asks for information on the value of new infrastructure, and repair and maintenance (R&M) of existing infrastructure.

You will be asked to provide information on the value of work undertaken by your business. Value of work refers to estimates of chargeable work carried out during the month; meaning work started, in progress, or completed.

Include:

  • work done by your own business on its own business premises
  • fixtures, equipment and tools your business made and used in construction
  • materials your business used, overheads and profits
  • labour costs on your payroll

Exclude:

  • VAT
  • payments made to subcontractors
  • payments made to consultants or architects
  • fixtures, equipment and tools your business made for sale
  • materials your business sold
  • value of land

questions.title: During the period {{ metadata['ref_p_start_date'] | format_date }} to {{ metadata['ref_p_end_date'] | format_date }}, did {{ first_non_empty_item(metadata['trad_as'], metadata['ru_name']) }} carry out any work on infrastructure?
questions.description: If you are a fitter or installer, you are included within the construction industry sector so should report your figures.

list: new infrastructure and repair and maintenance (R&M) of infrastructure
work on any residential buildings such as housing, flats or maisonettes
work on any industrial or commercial structures, such as factories, warehouses, offices health facilities or educational facilities

content.description: Infrastructure refers to non-residential buildings, facilities, or systems that are fundamental to the functioning of an area.

list: Gas, such as gas works and laying pipelines
Air transport, harbours, roads, and railways
Drainage, sewerage, and water such as reservoirs

blocks.title: Other construction work
blocks.description:
This section asks for information on the value of other construction work carried out on new structures for public, commercial and industrial projects, and repair and maintenance (R&M) of existing structures.

You will be asked to provide information on the value of work undertaken by your business. Value of work refers to estimates of chargeable work carried out during the month; meaning work started, in progress, or completed.

Include:

  • work on buildings which you hope to sell later for profit (speculative work)
  • work done by your business on its own premises
  • fixtures, equipment and tools your business made and used in construction
  • materials your business used, overheads and profits
  • labour costs on your payroll

Exclude:

  • work on infrastructure
  • work on residential buildings, for example housing, flats and maisonettes
  • VAT
  • payments made to subcontractors
  • payments made to consultants or architects
  • fixtures, equipment and tools your business made for sale
  • materials your business sold
  • value of land

blocks.title: Employment
blocks.description:
This section asks for information on the number of {{ first_non_empty_item(metadata['trad_as'], metadata['ru_name']) }}'s employees, and hours worked split by gender.

Include:

  • all workers paid directly from this business’s payroll(s)
  • those temporarily absent but still being paid, for example on maternity leave

Exclude:

  • subcontractors
  • agency workers paid directly from the agency payroll
  • voluntary workers
  • former employees only receiving a pension
  • self-employed workers
  • working owners who are not paid via PAYE

questions.title: On {{ metadata['employment_date'] | format_date }}, what was the number of employees for {{ first_non_empty_item(metadata['trad_as'], metadata['ru_name']) }}?
questions.description: An employee is anyone aged 16 years or over that your organisation directly pays from its payroll(s), in return for carrying out a full-time or part-time job or being on a training scheme.

list: all workers paid directly from this business’s payroll(s)
those temporarily absent but still being paid, for example on maternity leave

former employees only receiving a pension
